Award.AwardTitle: Type 1 - L02170320: Assessing and Improving the Scale Dependence of Ecosystem Processes in Earth System Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to assess and improve Earth system model simulations of the carbon cycle, ecosystem climate feedbacks, and ecosystem impact, mitigation, and adaptation metrics. The simulations will focus on decadal timescales for forests of northern and eastern U.S. The research will simulate the decadal scale forcings including climate variability, climate change, and atmospheric CO2 trends and incorporate human perturbations from land use and nitrogen deposition. The simulation responses will include (i) the carbon cycle; (ii) the impacts on forest structure and community composition; and (iii) ecosystem feedbacks on climate variability and change. The research will test the hypothesis that land use and nitrogen deposition provide a larger perturbation to forest ecosystems, and resulting atmospheric feedback, than do climate variability, climate change, and atmospheric CO2 trends over decadal timescales. The Community Land Model (CLM), the land component of the Community Climate System Model/Community Earth System Model, includes the necessary statistical meteorological downscaling, carbon-nitrogen biogeochemistry, land use, and dynamic vegetation will be used to perform multi-scale simulations. Model simulations and comparisons with observational datasets will be used to test the role of land use history and resulting post-disturbance vegetation dynamics, biogeochemical cycles, nitrogen deposition, and their interactions for local- to regional-scale simulations.

This capacity and community building proposal establishes a framework to engage the university ecological, environmental sciences, and biogeoscience communities in the Community Land Model. Fellowships will be used to expand the education and research opportunities of six undergraduates, two graduate students, and one post-doctoral research associate beyond core ecological disciplines to include large-scale geophysical Earth system models. The CLM is a community model for university researchers. Developments gained from this award will allow regional and decadal simulations that take into account terrestrial ecosystems, their responses to environmental change, and their feedbacks on climate. The research extends the biogeochemical focus of Community Land Model from carbon and nitrogen biogeochemistry to include also stand characteristics such as age-structure, size-structure, canopy height, and community composition that are relevant for impact, mitigation, and adaptation studies. These model developments will allow for well-informed climate change adaptation and mitigation policy and stewardship of forest ecosystems in a changing environment

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth system models simulate the influence of terrestrial ecosystems, including the carbon cycle, on climate. This research assessed and improved Earth system model simulations of the carbon cycle and ecosystem-climate feedbacks over decadal timescales. The research improved simulation of the terrestrial carbon cycle and stomatal physiology in the Community Land Model (CLM), the terrestrial component of the Community Earth System Model (CESM); quantified the influence of decadal-scale climate variability, climate change, and atmospheric CO2 trends on the carbon cycle; examined the impacts of ozone damage on ecosystem processes; and examined the impacts of historical land-cover change on the climate of Northeast United States.

 1. Photosynthesis - The terrestrial carbon cycle is a prominent feedback with climate change. A key aspect of the carbon cycle is gross primary production (GPP; the carbon uptake during photosynthesis). Research conducted during this proposal used ecological theory and observations to improve the simulation of GPP in the CLM. An additional process is photosynthetic and respiration acclimation to warmer temperatures. Most Earth system models do not include this in their carbon cycle simulations. Simulations with the CLM show that models that do not include temperature acclimation likely underestimate the terrestrial carbon storage over the twenty-first century.

2. Litter decomposition - Another key aspect of the carbon cycle is carbon loss to the atmosphere during litter decomposition. We developed a framework to test the litter decomposition of Earth system models using data from the Long-term Intersite Decomposition Experiment Team (LIDET). Model developments based on ecological theory and the LIDET observations improved litter decomposition in the CLM.

3. Biological nitrogen fixation - Biological nitrogen fixation is a critical source of nitrogen to terrestrial ecosystems that regulates the carbon cycle. Yet there is no consensus on how to represent this key ecological process in Earth system models. Simulations with the CLM that used two alternative plausible parameterizations of nitrogen fixation highlighted the sensitivity of terrestrial carbon storage over the twenty-first century to this process.

4. Carbon cycle and climate variability - We introduced the concepts of unforced variability and time-of-emergence, key aspects of climate change detection and attribution, to terrestrial carbon cycle studies. The research showed that over the twenty-first century unforced, or natural, variability in land-atmosphere CO2 flux is larger than the forced response at decadal timescales in many areas of the world, precluding detection of the forced carbon cycle change. Only after several decades does the forced carbon signal consistently emerge, even for a business-as-usual radiative forcing scenario.

5. Stomatal physiology - Stomata are a key regulator of carbon uptake by terrestrial ecosystems during photosynthesis, as well as the partitioning of energy into sensible heat and latent heat (evapotranspiration). Two key aspects of stomatal physiology are the effect of soil moisture on stomatal conductance and the minimum conductance at night when stomata are closed. Research supported by this project improved the simulation of soil water stress on stomatal conductance in the CLM and demonstrated that observed nighttime stomatal conductance is higher than represented in models and increases transpiration rates.

6. Ozone damage - High concentrations of ozone damage leaves, generally reducing photosynthesis and stomatal conductance.
